item.title: Reticent Turnip
item.description: Please, Nameless Irrational Dread was my father's name. Call me AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description:
We are excited to present a Brain-Wide Map of neural activity during a complex decision-making behavior, a product of the monumental effort of 22 labs: 547 Neuropixels recordings in 267 brain regions from 115 mice collected in 11 labs üê≠ (1/8)
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.07.04.547681v2
#neuroscience

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: How does complex behavior emerge from hundreds of brain areas processing information related to sensation, decisions, actions, and prior beliefs? We tackled this question by recording spiking activity across the entire brain in mice engaged in the IBL decision-making task https://elifesciences.org/articles/63711. (2/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: With a battery of analysis tools, we examined which brain regions and in which order carried signals about visual stimuli, the mouse's choice, prior expectation, movements, and reward üìä. Explore our results at https://atlas.internationalbrainlab.org/?alias=bwm and the data for each recording at https://viz.internationalbrainlab.org/app (‚è≤Ô∏èfirst loading can take time) (3/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: Visual stimuli elicited transient responses in traditional visual areas followed by ramping activity in midbrain and hindbrain regions, consistent with their role in decision making. üí° (4/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: The upcoming choice (before the first movement on a trial) was represented across the cortex, basal ganglia, thalamus, midbrain, hindbrain, and cerebellum. ü§∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è(5/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: The neural representation of movement and feedback/reward consumption were particularly widespread, reflecting brain-wide changes in neural activity. üß† (6/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description:
Surprisingly, the block prior was represented by few neurons in very few regions. To investigate this further, we devoted a whole companion paper to it, where additional analyses discovered widespread representations of the prior. (7/8)
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.07.04.547684v1

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description:
Do you want to know how your favorite brain region is involved in complex decision making? Explore or download the data to find out: https://www.internationalbrainlab.com/data! üíªThis work was generously funded by @SimonsFdn and @wellcometrust.
#neuroscience
(8/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description:
üö®Pre-print alert üö®Yes that‚Äôs right, we‚Äôre publishing not one, but two, pre-prints! Here we use the *electrophysiology data* from the Brain Wide Map as well as *widefield imaging data* to investigate the question ‚ÄúWhere in the brain is prior knowledge represented?‚Äù Recordings in 267 brain regions from 121 mice (1/8)
#neuroscience
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.07.04.547684v1

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: In the IBL task, the prior probability that the stimulus appeared on the right side switched in a random and uncued manner between 0.2 and 0.8 in blocks of trials. Mice leverage their prior knowledge of this block structure to improve their performance and obtain more rewards üßÄ (2/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: Where is prior information about the state of the world represented in the brain? At one extreme, the brain might combine prior information with sensory evidence in high level decision-making brain regions, right before decisions are turned into actions. (3/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: At the other extreme, the brain might operate like a very large Bayesian network, in which probabilistic inference is the modus operandi in all brain regions and inference can be performed in all directions. (4/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: We found that prior information is encoded in more than 20% of brain regions which, remarkably, span all levels of processing, from early sensory areas (LGd, VISp) to motor regions (MOs, MOp, GRN) and high level cortical regions (ACCd, ORBvl). (5/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: Two different modalities (electrophysiology and widefield imaging [WFI]), different mice but same task! Having one shared canonical task allows us to run the same experiment in different modalities. We found very similar prior representations between modalities. (6/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description: This prior found in the neural activity is reflected in the behavior. Higher decoded priors are associated with a greater proportion of rightward choices. (7/8)

item.title: International Brain Laboratory
item.description:
This work provides a picture, at an unprecedented scale, of the neural processes underpinning prior information in decision-making, bringing evidence for the ‚ÄúBayesian network‚Äù model of the brain. Check out our many more results on our preprint. (8/8)
#neuroscience
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.07.04.547684v1

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
@internationalbrainlab
Really exciting, IBL. Congrats and kudos all around on this huge achievement!

item.title: Dena Goldblatt
item.description: @schoppik When NY can match Boston/Philly sports fan energy -- I'm talking, "we have to grease the lampposts" energy -- then we'll talk!

item.title: Yohan John ü§ñüß†
item.description: "However, these reactivations occur, not during prolonged offline periods, but at the boundaries between ongoing narrative events."Nice. I've been chewing over the idea that contextual transitions are where detailed information become pivotal.https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01331-6#Neuroscience
